p: Humanized mice models permit the testing of novel therapeutic approaches to control influenza, the identification of critical epitopes for vaccine development, the preclinical analysis of the human immune response against influenza vaccines, and the evaluation of vaccine cytotoxicity. Direct manipulation or boosting of the host immune system is being considered as an alternative therapeutic strategy, which will help the individuals to protect themselves against influenza virus [ 89]. An advanced strategy of augmenting the innate and adaptive immune response to infectious disease is to expand the γδ-T cells using phosphoantigens [ 90, 91, 92]. In huPBMC sreconstituted immunodeficient Rag2 −/−γc −/− mice ( Table 3) infected with H1N1 influenza A and H5N1 influneza A, phosphoantigen selectively activated and expanded Vδ2-T cells and controlled H1N1 infection, suggesting a new therapeutic approach [ 93].
